seriesMenu.title: The T series contains the following 16 lessons

entries.title: Lesson T1     a s d f g h j k l ;
Lesson T8     w y v backspace

lesson_T1.1.title: Lesson T1.1: Tutorial
text: Welcome to Lesson T1
In the T series of lessons, we will be learning to touch-type on the standard
keyboard.  I will introduce you to each letter on the keyboard, one at a time.
By the time you have completed this series, you will be able to type the entire
alphabet, the numbers, and most of the punctuation keys by touch.
If you have never taken any lessons in typing before, please be patient.  Typing
is not difficult but it does take a lot of practice.  Avoid the tendency to
look down at your fingers while typing.  This is a very bad habit and is hard
to break later.  If you hit the wrong key, I will let you know.
If you have always used the hunt-and-peck method, you will have an even harder
time keeping yourself from looking.  Don't be surprised if you find touch
typing slower than your old ways.  It may be slower when you first start.
But, touch typing is far faster once you get the hang of it.
If you can already touch type, you should be able to go through these lessons
fairly quickly.  Or, you may want to go directly to the S series.

lesson_T1.2.title: Lesson T1.2: Tutorial
text: The Home Keys
In order to hit the correct keys by touch alone, you must always know where your
fingers are.  The way to do this is to have a special place for each finger.
This key is called the HOME position.
Place the first finger of your right hand on the J-key.  Now, place your second
finger on the K-key, your third finger on the L-key, and your fourth-finger on
the ;-key (the one with the : and ; on it).
Similarly place the four fingers of your left hand on the F, D, S, and A-keys.
Place your right thumb over the SPACE bar.  (Henceforth, always hit the SPACE
bar with this thumb.)  Now, lift all your fingers slightly so that they are
poised just over the keys.  Each finger should be just barely touching its home
key.  This is an electronic keyboard and does not take much pressure to ac-
cidentally press the key down.
Learn these positions well.  Whenever you are about to type a line, look at your
fingers and make sure they are in the HOME position.  Then don't look at them
again.

lesson_T1.3.title: Lesson T1.3: Tutorial
text: Drill Patterns
For the rest of this lesson, I will display some text in an exercise, usually
with some brief instructions above it.
All you have to do is type in the characters that you see in the exercise.
If you hit the correct key, I will print it underneath the exercise.  If you
make a mistake, I will display an error character in place of the letter that
you got wrong.  In either event, just keep going by typing the next letter.
When you have finished typing the line, hit the RETURN key.  To do this, extend
the little finger of your right hand over to the RETURN key.  Hit the key and
zip the finger back to its home position.  Be careful not to let your other
fingers move far from their home positions in the process.  Also, be careful
not to type an extra space at the end of the line.
Repeat the exercise until you make no more than a couple of mistakes, and
ideally none at all.  Don't forget to use your right thumb for the SPACE bar.

lesson_T1.4.instructions: Hit the F-key four times with the first finger of your left hand.

lesson_T2.1.title: Lesson T2.1: Tutorial
text: In this lesson, we will review the letters that you have already practiced
and will add the letters E, G, and H and the period.
When you reach for any of these keys, be sure to return your finger to its
home position.  For example, to hit the H-key, move the first finger of your
right hand (the J-finger) slightly to the left.  Tap the H-key and immediately
bring your finger back over the J.
If you lose track of where your fingers are, guess.  Don't look!

lesson_T3.11.title: Lesson T3.11: Tutorial
text: The next key we are going to practice is the right shift key.
Whenever you want to capitalize a key on the left side, you must use the
right shift-key.  To do so, follow these steps:
a.)  Without moving your first finger from the J-key, swing the
fourth finger of your right hand over to the SHIFT-key and
hold it down.
b.)  Strike the key that you want to type with your left hand.
c.)  Immediately bring your fourth finger back to the ;-key.

lesson_T3.15.title: Lesson T3.15: Drill

jjj Dr. jjj Sr. jjj Fr. jjj

lesson_T4.6.title: Lesson T4.6: Tutorial
text: The Left-Shift key
To capitalize letters on the right-side of the keyboard:
1.)  Move your A-finger to the LEFT-shift key and hold it down.
2.)  Strike the key that you want to capitalize with your right hand.
3.)  Immediately swing your A-finger back to its home position.

lesson_T5.12.title: Lesson T5.12: Tutorial
text: Speed Exercises
From now on, I will be mixing speed exercises in with the lessons.
I time you as you type an exercise; in speed exercises, you should take note of
your speed, and aim to increase it.  At the end of an exercise, I will calculate
your typing speed and convert in into words per minute (WPM).  I will also
count each of the mistakes you make and display the total number of errors.
If you make a mistake, I will show this with an error character in place of
the character you should have typed.  Just keep going and try to make as few
errors as possible.

lesson_T5.13.title: Lesson T5.13: Speed Test
lesson_T5.13.text: Sarah has liked knitting all her life.

lesson_T5.14.title: Lesson T5.14: Speed Test
lesson_T5.14.text: She looked past her garden to the fields and longed to see the other side.

lesson_T5.15.title: Lesson T5.15: Speed Test
lesson_T5.15.instructions: Hit RETURN at the end of each line in a paragraph.
text: All the sane people in this area sold their gold
right at the start.  The insane ones held their
gold and later it paid off.

lesson_T5.16.title: Lesson T5.16: Speed Test
text: One fine afternoon the king had an idea.  He
sent a letter to all the lords and ladies of
his land.  He asked for a great feast.  His
people prepared roasts.  His jester did a jig.
All the people left hoping to do it again.

lesson_T6.11.instructions: You should be aiming for 15 WPM.  If you do better, work on accuracy.

refers to a kind of bird and the stuff that is used in
flags.  English sure is a strange language.

ment about a commotion at the

produced a micro-organism in the

special kind of bacteria that
consumes crude oil.  The talk is
that it is being patented for use
on oil spills at sea.

Thanks,
Mrs. Carmichael

lesson_T8.14.title: Lesson T8.14: Tutorial
text: The Backspace
Most of the programs that you use will allow you to correct your mistakes by
using the BACKSPACE and/or DELETE keys.  These keys will generally delete the
previous character that you typed.  This feature is one of the principal
advantages of a word-processing system over a conventional typewriter.
I refuse to accept either of these keys during a drill pattern.  (You should
keep practicing until you get it right!)  But, I will accept either a BACK-
SPACE or a DELETE during a speed drill.  I will remove the error characters
but I still count it as an error in my totals.
If you do chose to use the DELETE or BACKSPACE keys, hit the key with your
;-finger and immediately return your fingers to the home position.

lesson_T8.15.title: Lesson T8.15: Speed Test
lesson_T8.15.instructions: Let's try our speed on some nursery rhymes!
text: Mary had a little lamb
Its fleece was white as snow
And every where that Mary went
The lamb was sure to go.

lesson_T8.16.title: Lesson T8.16: Speed Test
text: Jack and Jill went up a hill to fetch a pail of water.
Jack fell down and broke his crown and Jill came tumbling after.

lesson_T8.17.title: Lesson T8.17: Speed Test
text: Little Miss Muffet sat on a tuffet
Eating her curds and whey.
Along came a spider
Who sat down beside her
And frightened Miss Muffet away.

lesson_T8.18.title: Lesson T8.18: Speed Test
text: Hey, diddle diddle--
The cat and the fiddle
The cow jumped over the moon.
The little dog laughed to see such sport,
And the dish ran away with the spoon.

lesson_T10.1.title: Lesson T10.1: Drill
lesson_T10.1.instructions: Let's review the entire alphabet before starting the number keys.
lesson_T10.1.text: abcd efg hijk lmnop qrs tuv wx yz

lesson_T10.3.title: Lesson T10.3: Drill
lesson_T10.3.instructions: Use the shift key for each letter (Do not use the CAPS LOCK key)

lesson_T10.4.title: Lesson T10.4: Drill
lesson_T10.4.instructions: Now, review the punctuations that you've had.

lesson_T10.5.title: Lesson T10.5: Tutorial
text: Numeric Keys
The computer has two sets of numeric keys.  One set--directly above the
alphabetic keys--conforms to the standard for typewriter keyboards.  The other
set--to your right--resembles a calculator keypad.  In this typing series we
will be concerned only with the standard numeric keys on the main keyboard.
If you would like to learn to touch type on a numeric keypad, use the N-series
lessons instead.
The numeric keys are in the same place on almost every keyboard that you are
likely to encounter.  The only possible exception is on some very old type-
writers, which may lack a 1 key.  If this is the case on any keyboard you come
across, you will have to use the L-key in place of the 1.
This lesson series contains a few exercises that ask you to type this way, using
the L-key in place of 1.  Unless you specifically need to do this, you should
probably skip these exercises.

lesson_T10.6.title: Lesson T10.6: Drill
lesson_T10.6.instructions: Let's start by using the 1-key, since we have one.  Use your A-finger.

lesson_T10.7.title: Lesson T10.7: Drill
text: a1q qa1 qz1 az1 aq1 a1z
111 and 111 ate 111 any 111
If 11 men each catch 11 fish in 11 days, how many fish were caught?

lesson_T10.8.title: Lesson T10.8: Drill
lesson_T10.8.text: sss s2s sss s2s sss s2s

lesson_T10.9.title: Lesson T10.9: Drill
text: sss s2w sss 2xw sss w2x sss
222 saw 222 was 222 wet 222
The 2 men were 2 late 2 catch the 2 PM train.

lesson_T10.10.title: Lesson T10.10: Drill
lesson_T10.10.text: ddd d3d ddd d3d ddd d3d ddd

lesson_T10.11.title: Lesson T10.11: Drill
text: ddd d3e ddd d3c ddd e3c ddd
333 did 333 cat 333 eat 333
1 plus 2 is 3.  11 plus 22 is 33.  111 plus 222 is 333.

lesson_T10.12.title: Lesson T10.12: Drill
lesson_T10.12.instructions: The last number we will practice today is the 4-key.  (Use your F-finger.)
lesson_T10.12.text: fff f4f fff f4f fff f4f

text: fff f4r fff 4vr fff 4vr fff
444 for fff rat 444 vet 444
Flight 423 leaves from gate 42 at 4:24.
As the 3 musketeers say: 1 4 all, and all 4 1.
If 1/4 plus 2/3 is 11/12, what is 1/2 plus 1/3?

lesson_T10.14.title: Lesson T10.14: Speed Test
lesson_T10.14.instructions: Try your speed on this line:
lesson_T10.14.text: Our team won 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place at the 12th annual outing.

lesson_T10.15.title: Lesson T10.15: Drill
lesson_T10.15.instructions: Old typewriters may not have a 1 key; here we use the L-key as a 1.
lesson_T10.15.text: One dozen is l2.  A gross is l2 dozen or l44.

lesson_T10.16.title: Lesson T10.16: Drill
lesson_T10.16.instructions: Again, using the L-key as a 1.  You may want to skip this exercise.
text: In both octal and decimal, ll times ll is l2l.  And, 3 minus 4 is -l.
But in octal, l2 is not divisible by 3.

It is a 727 with 4 stops.  With all those stops it takes almost 7 hours.

Her team was assigned to zone 8 of quadrant 828.  Send 8 more agents.

Oh, 99 bottles of beer on the wall, 99 bottles of beer.

lesson_T11.10.title: Lesson T11.10: Drill
text: Dear Sirs:  The 10:00 meeting on March 10 has been postponed until 10:30.
The 10:30 meeting was moved to 11:00 in Room 302.
But, Room 302 can only hold 10 people.  We will need Conference Room 10.

lesson_T11.11.title: Lesson T11.11: Speed Test
text: Zip codes are arranged so that the first 3 digits
designate the regional office and the last 2
digits designate the local branch.  The numbering
is roughly east to west.  That is, numbers
starting with 0 are in New England, numbers
starting with 1 are the New York area, etc.
There are notable exceptions to this rule,
however.  The Virgin Islands are south of
Florida, but their Zip Codes start with 00.

lesson_T11.12.title: Lesson T11.12: Speed Test
text: The new nine digit zip codes have upset quite a
few people.  It was bad enough being referred to
as 73218.  But now, we will have to remember
numbers like 73218-4208.  The worst hit will be
the companies whose mailing list programs were
poorly designed.  Those unstructured programs
will be very difficult to change.

lesson_T12.17.title: Lesson T12.17: Speed Test

lesson_T12.21.title: Lesson T12.21: Speed Test

lesson_T13.1.title: Lesson T13.1: Tutorial
text: There is no Lesson 13!  Don't you know that 13 is an unlucky number?
If you have completed Lessons T1 through T12, then you are now ready
to call yourself a touch typist.  You have learned to touch type all
of the keys which are standardized!  You can now begin the S-series
of lessons if you would like.  (If you come across a punctuation symbol
which you have not learned, simply look for it.  Use the appropriate finger
for the shifted numeric keys.  Use your ;-finger for all the keys on the
right-hand side.)
We will practice touch typing on the keyboard layout for the remaining
lessons.

lesson_T14.3.title: Lesson T14.3: Drill
text: ;'; 'tis ;'; isn't ;'; 'tis too ;';
What's this I've got?  Isn't this yesterday's paper?  Where's today's?
Can't you find anything?  It's right next to Dad's chair.

lesson_T14.4.title: Lesson T14.4: Drill

lesson_T14.5.title: Lesson T14.5: Drill

"It's the answers to tomorrow's quiz", answered Suzy.
"If you promise not to tell," she continued, "I'll give you a copy."

lesson_T14.8.text: Tomorrow's quiz!  What if we get caught?  We'll be expelled!

lesson_T14.9.title: Lesson T14.9: Drill
lesson_T14.9.text: He'll never suspect a thing!  We'll get some answers wrong to fool him.

lesson_T15.1.title: Lesson T15.1: Tutorial
text: In this lesson we will be practicing the special symbols which you will need
for BASIC or other programming languages.  I won't give you too much practice
with these symbols right now.  You should be able to get plenty of exercise by
simply typing in programs.

lesson_T15.2.title: Lesson T15.2: Drill
lesson_T15.2.instructions: Use your ;-finger for the equals key.

lesson_T15.6.title: Lesson T15.6: Drill
lesson_T15.6.instructions: Use your ;-finger for the plus sign.

lesson_T15.8.title: Lesson T15.8: Drill
lesson_T15.8.instructions: Use your L-finger for the greater-than key.
lesson_T15.8.text: lll l>l lll l>l lll l>l lll

lesson_T15.9.title: Lesson T15.9: Drill

lesson_T15.10.title: Lesson T15.10: Drill
lesson_T15.10.instructions: Use your K-finger for the less-than key.

lesson_T15.11.title: Lesson T15.11: Drill

lesson_T15.12.title: Lesson T15.12: Drill
lesson_T15.12.instructions: Use your J-finger for the up-arrow key.

lesson_T15.13.title: Lesson T15.13: Drill
text: j^j X^2 j^j Y^3 j^j Z^4 j^j

lesson_T15.14.title: Lesson T15.14: Speed Test
text: 10 LET x=10
20 LET y=20
30 PRINT x+y/3
40 PRINT y/x*5
50 STOP

lesson_T15.15.title: Lesson T15.15: Speed Test
text: 10 REM Program to find square roots with using ^.5 feature
20 INPUT "What number do you want the square root of? ";s
40 y = s/x
60 IF ABS(x^2 - s) > s/1000 THEN 40
70 PRINT "The square root of ";s;" is ";x
80 STOP

lesson_T15.16.title: Lesson T15.16: Speed Test
lesson_T15.16.instructions: Press down the CAPS LOCK key to simplify typing in this BASIC program:
text: 100 REM PROGRAM TO SOLVE QUADRATIC EQUATION
125 PRINT "ENTER THE VALUES OF A, B, AND C WHERE:"
150 PRINT
175 PRINT "AX^2 + BX + C = 0"
200 INPUT A,B,C
210 IF A = 0 THEN 400
250 IF D < 0 THEN 500
275 PRINT "ONE ROOT IS: ";-B+SQR(D)/2/A
300 PRINT "THE OTHER IS: ";-B-SQR(D)/2/A
325 STOP
400 PRINT "NOT A QUADRATIC.  TRY AGAIN."
425 GOTO 100
500 PRINT "COMPLEX ROOTS.  TRY AGAIN."
525 GOTO 125

lesson_T16.1.title: Lesson T16.1: Tutorial
text: In this lesson we will be practicing the shifted numeric keys on the keyboard.
I will only be giving you practice in the keystroke motions.  Very few sentence
drills or speed exercises are included, since these keys are used so in-
frequently.
If you are typing something which includes one of these special characters and
you cannot remember where a key is, look.  But, always make sure to hit the key
with the correct finger.  If you do use the key often, you will eventually
learn where it is without looking.  Since these keys are used infrequently and
may be in different places on most other keyboards, or even totally missing,
speed is not important.

lesson_T16.2.title: Lesson T16.2: Drill
lesson_T16.2.instructions: Use your S-finger for the at-sign.
lesson_T16.2.text: sss s@s sss s@s sss s@s sss

lesson_T16.3.title: Lesson T16.3: Drill
text: s@s at@ s@s w@x s@s S@w s@s
s@s wax s@s mix s@s @we s@s

lesson_T16.4.title: Lesson T16.4: Drill
lesson_T16.4.instructions: Use your D-finger for the pound-sign (also called the number-sign).
lesson_T16.4.text: ddd d#d ddd d#d ddd d#d ddd

lesson_T16.5.title: Lesson T16.5: Drill
text: d#d d#e d#d 3#c d#d #c# d#d
d#d cat d#d dog d#d eat d#d

lesson_T16.6.title: Lesson T16.6: Drill
lesson_T16.6.instructions: Use your F-finger for the dollar-sign.
lesson_T16.6.text: fff f$f fff f$f fff f$f fff

lesson_T16.7.title: Lesson T16.7: Drill
text: f$f r$v f$f v$4 f$f 4$r f$f
f$f rave f$f fare f$f $10.00 f$f
Joe keeps cryptic inventory bills like:  4# @ $5.00/# or 6# @ $4.50/#.

lesson_T16.8.title: Lesson T16.8: Drill
lesson_T16.8.instructions: Use your F-finger for the percent sign as well.
lesson_T16.8.text: fff f%f fff f%f fff f%f fff

lesson_T16.9.title: Lesson T16.9: Drill
text: f%f two f%f ran f%f bug f%f
If a $25.00 item is sold at a 10% discount, it will cost $22.50.
But, a 10% markup on a item selling for $22.50 is only $24.75!  How come?

lesson_T16.10.title: Lesson T16.10: Drill
lesson_T16.10.instructions: Use your J-finger for the ampersand.
lesson_T16.10.text: jjj j&j jjj j&j jjj j&j jjj

lesson_T16.12.title: Lesson T16.12: Drill
lesson_T16.12.text: j&j you&me j&j he&she j&j M&M j&j

lesson_T16.13.title: Lesson T16.13: Tutorial
text: The End
You have now completed the T-series of these lessons.  If you have not already
done so, you should now start the N-series or S-series.
There are a few keys which we have not studied.  If you decide to touch-type
these keys, use the closest finger.  Thus, the ESC, TAB, and CAPS LOCK keys
use the A-finger.  And, the keys to the far right (BACKSPACE, DELETE, RETURN,
}, {, etc.) use the ;-finger.  The upper keys (F1, F2, etc.) are not usually
touch typed as the reach is too far.  If you can reach them, fine.
The CONTROL and ALT keys are difficult to touch type, but are treated like the
SHIFT keys whenever possible.  For example, for Alt-Q, hold down the ALT key
with your ;-finger and then hit the Q with your A-finger.  Certain command
sequences, such as Ctrl-S, are hard to do this way.  Many people simply hold
the CONTROL-key down with their A-finger and then hit the other key with what-
ever finger is convenient (usually the F-finger in this case).
